Award.AwardTitle: NSF Travel Grant Support for IEEE/ACM CCGrid 2015 Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will assist approximately 15 United States-based graduate students to attend the 15th IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Cluster, Cloud and Grid Computing (CCGrid 2015) that will be held May 4-7, 2015. Participation in conferences such as IEEE/ACM CCGrid is an extremely important part of graduate student research and career development, providing the opportunity for them to present their own work, attend panel and keynote speech sessions, attend doctoral symposium, interact with peers and more senior researchers, and expose themselves to leading edge work in the field of cluster, cloud and grid computing. The support requested in this proposal will enable more participation of the US-based graduate students who would otherwise be unable to attend CCGrid 2015. Women and minority candidates will be particularly encouraged to apply.

The student activities planned this year are separated into three categories: (1) Conference planning, where senior researchers who are more experienced with the conference will explain the various events at the conference and work with individual students to custom create an agenda for each student, (2) Posters and Doctoral Symposium where all students participating in this program are required to present a short talk during the conference and present a poster describing their research areas at the poster session, and (3) Lunchtime Mentorship Activities, where the students would interact with senior researchers, discussing various topics of interest with them, such as (a) how to write effective papers, (b) careers in academia, industry and national labs, and (c) paper presentation techniques.

At the end of he conference, travel grantees will be asked to write up about their experiences and what they learned from these discussions. A short report will be generated at the end of the conference explaining the full extent of these activities, and published on the conference website. A few selected students may be invited to participate in the report generation process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project funded the travel expenses of selected graduate students from various U.S institutions to attend the IEEE/ACM CCGrid 2015: 15th IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Cluster, Cloud and Grid Computing. The travel expenses included the costs of the student's conference registration, five nights ofconference hotel stay, and a flight ticket (from U.S Carrier only), with a total up to $1666 USD for each student.

The students participated in several activities during the conference: poster presentations and discussions, presenting their theses topics, attending the conference technical program, and lunchtime mentorship discussions with senior researchers and postdocs. At the end of the project, the students submitted their travel experience reports. According to the feedback from the students, the conference was a success, where they had a very enriching and positive experience, thanks to the travel awards from the NSF. 

The following student activities were conducted at the IEEE/ACM CCGrid 2015 conference.

Travel Awardee Meet and Greet

A greeting event was held on the first day of the conference during dinnertime. The goal was to meet and greet the student awardees and advise them on how to take advantage of what the conference has to offer. This was helpful for them to focus their time on the relevant parts of the conference and get advice for their oncoming technical presentations. Furthermore, the students received quality feedback and advices from senior researchers, Prof. Michela Taufer from the University of Delaware and Dr. Pavan Balaji from Argonne National Laboratory, who mentored this meeting.

Technical Program Participation

The students participated in the technical program of the conference, whether by presenting a paper, a poster, or discussing their Ph.D thesis topic in the doctoral symposium session. In addition, they also attended several technical sessions of their interests. This was for them a perfect opportunity to showcase their experience, get in touch with other researchers with the same interests, extend their knowledge from other technical presentations or discussions with other researchers and students, and extend their network relations.

Lunchtime Mentorship Activities

The students were gathered during lunchtime to join table with senior researchers, where the students were honored with the presence of Prof. Daniel Katz, Senior Fellow at the University of Chicago and Argonne National Laboratory and Program Director in the Division of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure at the NSF, and Prof. Rosa M. Badia, researcher at Spanish National Research Council and manager of the Grid computing and Clusters group at the Barcelona Supercomputing Center. In addition, some postdoctoral researchers were also present to contribute to the discussions with their early career experience. The students were actively involved in the discussion, where questions evolved around various topics from advices to present research contributions in papers and talks, to career related questions, such as the difference between working in academia, industry and national laboratories.
